componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Ryan Brinkman from JP Morgan. Please proceed.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Could you just provide a little bit more collar, maybe on the trend of Lifestyle?  It looks like the change in revenues, ex-currency inflected higher to up 39% year-over-year this quarter versus 22% year-over-year last quarter. What accounts for that incr
componenttext: Could you just provide a little bit more collar, maybe on the trend of Lifestyle?  It looks like the change in revenues, ex-currency inflected higher to up 39% year-over-year this quarter versus 22% year-over-year last quarter. What accounts for that increase? Is it mostly on the automotive/audio side, or is there anything to report on the consumer side of things?

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: It’s both Ryan.  We had an excellent growth in car-audio, almost 28%. But then you need to do some put and take.  At 3% of the growth in Lifestyle came from neodymium surcharge which we billed, and that came at 0 margin. So that’s the thing. So 28% an
componenttext: It’s both Ryan.  We had an excellent growth in car-audio, almost 28%. But then you need to do some put and take.  At 3% of the growth in Lifestyle came from neodymium surcharge which we billed, and that came at 0 margin. So that’s the thing. So 28% and you can adjust for 3% neodymium.  We had a healthy gain of also double digit in Home and Multimedia, and for those of you who have been following Harman a long time, our consumer business, now we call it Home and Multimedia under Lifestyle, traditionally has struggled and not made money, but now we are mid-single digit operating profits.  So, we’ve made a turnaround, and we are double digits growth. So all in all very good year for Lifestyle. And it also underscores why we made this change when we put consumer and car-audio together, we are able to see the branding and marketing dollars really helping us connect consumers those who are buying home office, on-the-go products and the car-audio brands. And we are seeing the take rates going up, and I expect this division to continue to do margin expansion and topline expansion in ’13,’14’and ’15.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks that’s really helpful to get that breakdown and collar.  Just on infotainment, it looks like your FY13 infotainment guidance does not seem to imply margin expansion relative to what you were able to achieve in FY12, maybe on not flowing th
componenttext: Great, thanks that’s really helpful to get that breakdown and collar.  Just on infotainment, it looks like your FY13 infotainment guidance does not seem to imply margin expansion relative to what you were able to achieve in FY12, maybe on not flowing through the, what was a real strong quarter this quarter. I’m just wondering, you know, what is the driver of that assumption though given that you should continue to transition clients, from the lower margin customized to the higher margin scalable systems over the course of the year?

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Couple of things.  First of all we should explain to you that we confirmed the range of our guidance. And if you look at our range of guidance for 2012, for Infotainment it was $160 million to $175 million operating profit, and we landed at $182 million.
componenttext: Couple of things.  First of all we should explain to you that we confirmed the range of our guidance. And if you look at our range of guidance for 2012, for Infotainment it was $160 million to $175 million operating profit, and we landed at $182 million. So, we did beat it nicely. So, having said that, rather than tweaking the guidance for one division here and there, we just left it. We wanted to come out, we’re not changing our guidance, we’re leaving it as it is. Actually midpoint of the guidance, you know, tells you where we’ll be, and we are going to definitely have an improvement.  So, we already landed 7.6% this year, the guidance it starts with 7 and goes to 8.2 if you the quick math, for revenue and operating income. So, clearly we have a possibility to come out in the top half of the guidance, and hopefully even beat. But a lot of things are still uncertain. And the last item Ryan, which is important, also Chris’s point and other colleagues, that some of the programs are rolling off in ’13, and our high margin programs would be early in the ramp-up phase that’s why revenue is ’13 slightly  breathing sort of exercise, ’14, ’15 we hit up on the high gear again. And that would be good margin expansion at the same time, good top line because we’ll be ramping a bunch of programs.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Last question you reported that your China revenues were up 42% year-over-year, which is very interesting. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about -- just qualitatively segment by segment what the drivers are for the sales in your 3 different
componenttext: Last question you reported that your China revenues were up 42% year-over-year, which is very interesting. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about -- just qualitatively segment by segment what the drivers are for the sales in your 3 different divisions in China or other emerging markets.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. China, let’s start with China. China did of course -- all 3 divisions had very good growth that’s why the average was 31% for the company. But Lifestyle literally exceeded everything in car-audio. As I have said in my earlier calls, emerging mar
componenttext: Okay. China, let’s start with China. China did of course -- all 3 divisions had very good growth that’s why the average was 31% for the company. But Lifestyle literally exceeded everything in car-audio. As I have said in my earlier calls, emerging market consumers when they’re buying cars happens to be the first time in their family if not first time in their village, first time in the city. And they want to have some things in it which they can appreciate and audio is one of those. So take rates in emerging markets will continue to go up and that’s why building brand is very important. So you will see that. And Infotainment -- so let’s stick with Lifestyle first, Lifestyle had good healthy, more than 50% growth, which is phenomenal, that’s coming from consumer products, and car-audio. Then of course Infotainment we had also good 30%, 35% growth and Professional had in 20s. So we’re building a lot of airports and some of the revenues would be booked perhaps in other year. So I expect all 3 divisions to hit 30-plus-percent growth or even higher in 2013. Moving on to China -- I mean India and Brazil or Russia. Brazil we have an opportunity because we have not even begun our operation in infotainment. We only do pro-audio and part of car-audio so opportunities are immense. I expect ’13, ’14 to take us to the next level. India with good growth but with the $200-plus- million order from Tata motors and that will commissioned, engineered and shipped out of India, I think we’ll start to see good development not in ’13, but ’14 will be [indiscernible] year for India. But ’13 should be a good year for Lifestyle and for pro-audio anyway. And Russia, I think we had a good development we don’t do anything in infotainment in Russia, and we do a little bit of pro-audio, little bit of Lifestyle and that to mainly consumer. But Russia is on our radar screen for ’13 and ’14. So we as a management, first focused on China, then focused on Brazil then India and Russia and now all 4 will be on sort of top gear.

Again Ravi, it’s all about our focus as management is expanding and our country obligations are expanding, you will see more focus to go in those areas.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Perfect, that’s totally fine.  And one last big picture question for you, Dinish, what’s the benefit of bringing Interchange in house?  I mean is this something that you’re going to be looking to do going forward?  Or was there something specific he
componenttext: Perfect, that’s totally fine.  And one last big picture question for you, Dinish, what’s the benefit of bringing Interchange in house?  I mean is this something that you’re going to be looking to do going forward?  Or was there something specific here that you wanted to get in terms of skills or patents or something?

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Not so much patents, but it is to do with open source solutions.  We got out of Q&X operating systems Ravi, more than a couple years now.  We want to be operating system agnostic.  So we continue to use Q&X as our fundamental operating system, which we st
componenttext: Not so much patents, but it is to do with open source solutions.  We got out of Q&X operating systems Ravi, more than a couple years now.  We want to be operating system agnostic.  So we continue to use Q&X as our fundamental operating system, which we still believe most robust from safety point of view.  But we are not developing Android based infotainment, Lenox and Droid, Microsoft, everything, so we will have -- and systems will not be unique to one operating system.  The colonel could be one thing and apps could be written in something else.  It’s going to be a hybrid system, which is what actually [indiscernible] in Europe is sort of calling for and talking to more BMW and Audis who lead the space with us. They seem to be very comfortable with the strategy we have, so this little company we acquired, this will give us additional horsepower to expedite our engineering development work.  In addition, we’re also adding some 100 software engineering resources and Google and Droid based competence right here in Midwest, in [indiscernible] and Chicago area.  Lots of people from Google actually have left to join Harman.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Understood and just speaking of Q&X, RIM is obviously having a few difficulties right now.  Can you remind us again how things stand between you and your ability to use Q&X expecially if RIM kind of licenses someone else or partners with someone else?
componenttext: Understood and just speaking of Q&X, RIM is obviously having a few difficulties right now.  Can you remind us again how things stand between you and your ability to use Q&X expecially if RIM kind of licenses someone else or partners with someone else?

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: That’s a great question for all of our listeners.  When we sold Q&X to RIM, we took care of our shareholders interest for next 20 years.  We have access to the source code of Q&X no matter what change of hands happen.  Even if the company goes so south
componenttext: That’s a great question for all of our listeners.  When we sold Q&X to RIM, we took care of our shareholders interest for next 20 years.  We have access to the source code of Q&X no matter what change of hands happen.  Even if the company goes so south that no one can save it, we still will have access to it.  And frankly speaking, we have as much confidence in Q&X as RIM today.  And we have an excellent relationship, so there’s no issue of access to source and access to development for next 18, 20 years.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, and just in Europe just in case things get much worse very quickly, what’s your temporary workforce over there as a percentage of the overall workforce?
componenttext: Okay, and just in Europe just in case things get much worse very quickly, what’s your temporary workforce over there as a percentage of the overall workforce?

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Typically, Adam what we have done now and this is a transformation over the last three years, we used to have almost 100% permanent workforce and now we’ve gone almost 80/20 model.  So we have 80% permanent workforce.  And to deal with increase in deman
componenttext: Typically, Adam what we have done now and this is a transformation over the last three years, we used to have almost 100% permanent workforce and now we’ve gone almost 80/20 model.  So we have 80% permanent workforce.  And to deal with increase in demand like in 2012, we are able to bring in temporary workforce, which is easy to reduce if the demand goes down.  It’s of course much easier to work with in Hungary, which is our largest manufacturing in the world, much easier to deal with Mexico and China and other places.  So that’s  I made a big point in my earlier comments that we are actually very well positioned now to deal with economic ups and downs when it comes to our manufacturing cost.  We can adjust it rather quickly than in the past.

And then, Dinesh, as we look at 2013 in your guidance here and you know, I understand there’s a range there, but if you take the midpoint of the range and we look at where the earnings performance comes from, you know, you’ve done a great job on the Infotainment side, but incrementally here the Lifestyle and Professional are going to be the primary earnings drivers in 2013.  We haven’t really talked about what’s going on in those businesses.  Can you take a little bit of time of what the revenue drivers and the margin drivers are in those 2 pieces of business you are looking at 2013?

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: David, first of all, I was really smiling and happy.  You’re my hero because you’re asking me now Professional and Lifestyle questions.  In the past, all the calls, we spend 99% of the time on Infotainment, which I’m glad that because we have turned
componenttext: David, first of all, I was really smiling and happy.  You’re my hero because you’re asking me now Professional and Lifestyle questions.  In the past, all the calls, we spend 99% of the time on Infotainment, which I’m glad that because we have turned the corner.  You guys seem to be pleased with the way we’re doing. So let’s come back to Lifestyle and Professional.  You are absolutely spot on that Lifestyle and Pro had been neodymium.  And that is gone away.  We will not talk about neodymium even if the price is still high and we have dissolved that and we took care of that business. Second, Professional launched 140 brand new products earlier in the year, especially in the main bread and butter area of storage sound and [indiscernible] sound in the loud speaker area and that business is just taken off.  So I expect really to be beating our last year’s sales topline growth rate definitely in Pro.  I expect that.  And Lifestyle has done a very good job dealing with all this neodymium issue and ramping up correctional facility Mexico and [inaudible].  Both of these divisions, and that’s totally behind us so that should be falling off the bottom line for the margin expansion. At the same time, I’m getting ready in 2 weeks’ time to go to Berlin, we’ll have the world’s largest home multimedia show where we’ll launch the 25 brand new products.  That’s the highest I’ve ever seen.  No more than 5 products every year and this is 25 products.  So I think we expect quite a good topline at the same time you know we’re very disciplined when it comes to pricing and pricing premium.  So we’re holding on quite well, so I expect both of these divisions to grow topline with new products, to grow topline from the new markets and Pro and Lifestyle both will also benefit from North America, all the slow pickup, but nice pickup.  Both of them are seeing very good inquiry for the [indiscernible] .

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012

componenttext: Okay, great.  And then how much -- do you know off hand how much neodymium headwinds you have that -- to catch up yet in the first part of 2013 because I don’t think you got that all straightened away until part way through the year.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: 2012, we said last time that we will be done with this no matter what, that was a personal goal I made and the team made.  And we are done with it in terms of never mentioning that, even if it is a bit of a headwind, we will find ways to accomplish it.  M
componenttext: 2012, we said last time that we will be done with this no matter what, that was a personal goal I made and the team made.  And we are done with it in terms of never mentioning that, even if it is a bit of a headwind, we will find ways to accomplish it.  Mostly we have passed it on to our customers so it’s in their pricing and that’s, if neodymium goes down to where it used to be 1 year ago, then our customers will get a break, if not, it’s there.  At the same time, we have also had pretty advanced development in material sciences to find substitute to replace neo with better acoustics capabilities and we are doing that in design changes.  So I think between those, neodymium is quite under control. And in terms of capacity, margin expansion for neo hat would drop straight bottom line, you should count on that.  And then it comes to capacity in Mexico and China, there we’re going to be ramping -- we’re ramped up already, but all the products for China factory will be running at 80% production capacity.  That will help us fast expanding Asian market in China, India, Vietnam, Indonesia, they are really booming and so I expect topline to be much stronger than 2012. And in Lifestyle can come close to what they did last year, I’d be happy.  Last year was an amazing topline, which may or may not be sustainable.  We’ll see, but profit extension is the key.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Dinesh, I was wondering, I think sometimes people mistake what’s going on in the industries and actually, you know, don’t think about -- maybe they have the opposite argument they need to take, but on the General Motors thing, you’ve said before, yo
componenttext: Dinesh, I was wondering, I think sometimes people mistake what’s going on in the industries and actually, you know, don’t think about -- maybe they have the opposite argument they need to take, but on the General Motors thing, you’ve said before, you thought you could win them over but and that would be -- I don’t want to put words in your mouth, but clearly you said it would have to be economically beneficial for you guys.  And I’m wondering in light of that, given what’s going on, particularly in Europe and Asia, I know there’s a lot of concerns out there on the growth of the on the auto market, particularly on the low end.  What’s the sales process look like at this point in time?  In other words, I would imagine as competitive as things have gotten in certain sectors, and as much pressure as there are in people like a Fiat and Ford in Europe and so forth that what you guys have to offer them would be much more valuable going forward from a competitive point of view and from a cost point of view than when things are booming, for example, and they can sell whatever they make.  Am I -- is that a, you know, is that -- are you seeing that reflected from your conversations with customers?

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Doug, you tried not to put words in my mouth, but you sure did.  I mean, you said all the right things what I would have said.  First of all, the culture in this company is all about pricing and premium pricing.  So GM business is a win-win.  GM gets supe
componenttext: Doug, you tried not to put words in my mouth, but you sure did.  I mean, you said all the right things what I would have said.  First of all, the culture in this company is all about pricing and premium pricing.  So GM business is a win-win.  GM gets superb technology, the latest cutting edge and we get what we deserve for what we bring..  And then you mentioned the impact in Europe, the economy, what happens to Fiat, Chrysler and some of the European automakers, you know, that’s why we do track OEMs into 3 different categories. One, we say all OEMs do globally, they are going to grow about 4%, 4.5%.  Then we look at Harman OEMs, including Chrysler, Fiat, Hyundai, Tata, [indiscernible] German automakers, they’re going to go about 2%.  Then we look at Harman OEMs, pure luxury, Porsche, Audi, BMW, Tata.  They’re going to grow 0.3%.  So if you put it all together and do the weighted average, find out, we’re going to be growing 3 times the growth of the car companies, which means we’ll be taking market share and why can I say with such confidence?  Because we have production releases out in our hands already for the next 6 months and we’re quite pleased. And on top of that ,if I may, we’re seeing clearly all of these global players, they may see some slowdown in their mature markets, but they continue to see growth in India, China, Brazil, Russia.  In India, they’re starting from almost near 0, they’re growing 40%, 50% a year, Infotainment growth, car-audio growth.  And China would grow also from 15% to 20% a year.  So this is very healthy for us.  And since we are on the market, we’re on the ground, we have R&D, engineering, manufacturing, so I just want to make a quite point for the benefit of all listeners, that we’ve arrived where a good company should be. That means serve your customers close to where they are.  So we’re serving Chinese customers whether they are German automakers in China or Asian customers, we’re serving them from China. We’re serving German automakers from Germany from Hungary, American automakers from Mexico and the United States.  So logistic costs and also proximity saves us money and improves the quality. And you get premium from that from automakers.  The days are gone when Japanese pushed their technology and everything was coming from Japan.  It’s still does, by the way, for some of our competitors, but that’s really not going to allow you to be on top of the technology. One more thing I’ll point here, we opened last couple years with wonderful R&D lab in Palo Alto.  That’s expensive, but it’s very necessary to keep in touch with technology, which is happening in connected space.  We’re opening up another open source R&D, I mentioned in Ann Arbor and Chicago area to really be on the leading side and Android open-source systems. There’s a lot happening all towards the future.  We’re not about 1 quarter or 1 year maximization of profit or -- in fact the continuous improvement is coming because we took some very drastic steps 3 years ago, 2 years ago. So we will never deter to do that.  So all in all we feel good about it for 2013 in spite of some uncertainty. One could say am I cautiously optimistic? I think I’m more towards optimistic, but if you use the word cautiously that’s fine.

componenttext: And then lastly, Dinesh, we haven’t talked a lot at all  on the infotainment side as it relates to Mercedes. I don’t think you have a lot of business left there. But can you give us some perspective on where that stands -- that relationship stands today?

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well sure, first of all start with the relationship. We have a very good relationship. We will be launching  brand new system called NPV 5 [ph] early next year. And that will be the next generation system they will launch and that will go live. As you kno
componenttext: Well sure, first of all start with the relationship. We have a very good relationship. We will be launching  brand new system called NPV 5 [ph] early next year. And that will be the next generation system they will launch and that will go live. As you know historically, prior to my time coming into Harman, they did bring in 2 of the suppliers. So we continue to be 3 of us, 2 Japanese and 1 American, Harman. So between 3 of us we split roughly 1/3, 1/3 of their infotainment business and that’s sort of continuing. And there is a follow on award will be coming in the next 3 to 6 months which we are also bidding. So until then hold the horses for what it will look like next year. But on the audio side we also have a decent business. We did mention in our press release as well as slide deck that Harmon’s business with Mercedes has been extended on some of the models, that’s always very nice. And in terms of business I think since it’s not 10% of our sales we don’t put out in the 10K but it’s a healthy business.  It’s still our third or fourth largest business after BMW and VW group. Fiat Chrysler is now becoming third largest and Diamler is our fourth largest.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: I know you guys have mentioned before that you work with the Googles and Apples of the world as far as integrating the smartphone into the infotainment platform, but can you please talk about some of the competitive advantages that you have versus the Goo
componenttext: I know you guys have mentioned before that you work with the Googles and Apples of the world as far as integrating the smartphone into the infotainment platform, but can you please talk about some of the competitive advantages that you have versus the Googles and Apples of the world? Maybe it’s relationships or safety feature patents that you have in infotainment systems that they can’t necessarily replicate.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think you hit it David, active safety integration is the single biggest differentiator. Beyond that what goes in the car has 50 to 100 live sensors in an advanced car and you’ve got 5, 6 sub systems in the car and we are the primary provider. We have
componenttext: I think you hit it David, active safety integration is the single biggest differentiator. Beyond that what goes in the car has 50 to 100 live sensors in an advanced car and you’ve got 5, 6 sub systems in the car and we are the primary provider. We have a backbone, a software backbone. We write some 3 million to 3.5 million lines of code. So a lot of interaction with the live sensors, live information while cars are on the road. And we are able to manipulate that data and use that to determine the best route calculation. The best eco route if you’re on a green car. So a lot of those things would not be possible for smartphone’s ever because they would not have that access. And why so? Car companies are nervous, for good reasons, to allow more basic integration technology with smartphones, because smartphones carry hundreds of applications which will written by kids anywhere from age 13 to 17 years, especially in the case of Google. Any they really don’t know much about car and how this will interact with the safety of the car, a lot of other engine safety, breaking systems. So this is where the system competence and car eco-system knowledge comes into play. Therefore I’ve always said David, that going forward, both smart integration of the telephone and embedded system will co-exist. Because the starting points are fairly low and we will lead, both  will continue to integrate Google phone, Nokia phone, Microsoft, Blackberry and other phones will come in the market. Example is good. Look at Chrysler which we just launched last week. This will be agnostic to any phone, see if you just had an iPhone what good it is if somebody walks in the car with an Android phone then you are out of luck. So we will provide technology which will allow integration of any phone for basic level of turn-by-turn, point of interest, traffic advisory. So that’s the biggest advantage, and I think car companies get it. That’s why you can see in the last 6 to 12 months the kind of flurry of large awards we have received from BMW, GM and many others.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and thank you for joining the Harman fourth quarter and full-year 2012 investor and analyst call. I’m joined in Stamford, Connecticut today by our Chief Financial Officer Herbert Parker and our Vice President of Inves
componenttext:
Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and thank you for joining the Harman fourth quarter and full-year 2012 investor and analyst call. I’m joined in Stamford, Connecticut today by our Chief Financial Officer Herbert Parker and our Vice President of Investor Relations Robert Lardon.
We had an outstanding year, and I’m pleased to report solid progress with sales up 16% and operating income up 47% for the fiscal year, with a nice increase of 41% in earnings per share for the year.
I’m extremely proud to report that we continue to innovate and invest in technology. We added some 600 new patents and patents filings this past year, and our invention portfolio has grown to 4,400, almost doubled in last 5 years. Our strong pipeline of new products in our luxury branch and the expansion of our channels globally position us for healthy secular growth.
We are on the forefront of developing connected car technologies, with a focus on active driver safety. As you know, we successfully collaborate and integrate technologies from Google, Apple, Microsoft and other partners. Actually as a very good example, just couple days ago, Chrysler put out a press release, and let me talk about it. Harman just launched a latest infotainment system to Chrysler, it is called Uconnect. This will for the first time connect to a cellular network in the United States without an on-board smartphone. Just think of how many percent of Americans carry smartphone in the car, not too many. This is first in the industry that it is phone or network agnostic. The new technology will debut in the 2013 model Ram 1500 pickup truck and 2013 SRT Viper. This Harman technology will allow consumers to use voice command with a touch button command on the steering wheel, to do Bing-powered internet searches, read and write text messages and enter navigation destinations without multiple prompts. Vehicles equipped with this Harman technology will also be able to serve as a mobile hotspot. Chrysler’s infotainment chief, actually, Mario Zenios, called it “one-stop shop in connectivity, online apps and smartphone integration.”
So moving along, car companies have done very extensive research on consumer needs and technology solutions available. Embedded infotainment ranks very high on each automaker’s priority list, principally due to safety requirements and the need for full integration with the car’s sensors and other subsystems in the car. Research validates that embedded infotainment system penetration will continue to grow rapidly, and it will be complemented by smartphones. I remind everybody that only 20% of the cars currently have embedded infotainment system, and this is likely to go up to 50% with the next 5 years. In addition, basic telematics and basic connectivity will also grow in the car via smartphone integration. And it’s likely to go from less than 5% today to some 30% in 5 years. So these trends really put Harman right in the sweet spot of a big growth opportunity, given our leadership in automotive embedded infotainment system, design and a smartphone integration capability.
I also want to remind you that Harman has led smartphone integration and we will provide the service to car companies just like what we did with Chrysler this past week, just like what we are doing with BMW this fall. With or without an embedded system in the car, our record order intake for embedded infotainment system and the recent awards from leading automakers confirm our strategy and business model.
On that note, we are pleased to have scored several key wins during fiscal year 2012. We extended our relationship with BMW through a $2 billion-plus order that we shared with you on the last call. And earlier in the year, we booked a $400 million add-on award for Porsche-Volkswagen group.
To meet the growing demand for entry-level embedded infotainment systems, Harman launched a new scalable infotainment platform targeting entry and mixed segment vehicles. Not -- it didn’t take much. We had immediate success with this launch and we penetrated Asian automotive companies and one scalable next generation system orders from Tata Motors of India, China’s BIC, Changan, Geely brands and several others.
Today we are pleased to share with you a news update, major breakthrough award. We have received a significant new order from the world’s largest automaker, General Motors. This $900 million order will provide General Motors with a new, advanced, scalable infotainment technology. Our latest success in Europe, Asia and now North America with Chrysler, General Motors, further reinforce our leadership in these technology areas. It is important to emphasize that our sales by final destination are very diversified, as shown on Slide 8 of your deck.
The EU5 represents only 30% of the company’s sales; 74% of that 30% is in robust German market. Therefore, our exposure to European uncertainty is hardly any, because we have got nothing to do with Greece and several other slumping economies, so long Germany continues to do well.
Our strong sales base in BRIC markets has also reduced our dependence on mature Western economies. Our global marketing campaign featuring celebrity ambassadors such as Sir Paul McCartney, Maroon 5, Jennifer Lopez, Liu Huan, A.R. Rahman and Tim McGraw, is delivering increased brand awareness and improved automotive take rates in all our key markets globally.
Our emerging market growth during fiscal year 2012 has been outstanding. Amidst the infotainment and branded audio wins noted earlier, we have continued the expansion of our resources in high growth markets. In China, we opened Harman’s largest new manufacturing facility in Dandong, established a brand new engineering center in a city called Chengdu and inaugurated our second Chinese flagship store in Beijing. We continue to add resources at our multiple development facilities in India, China, United States and Germany.
We are strengthening our presence in Russia and our operations in Brazil as we pursue opportunities like 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics, 2014 FIFA World Cup and 2016 Rio Olympics, to just build on what we did successfully at London Olympics with our professional audio systems. In addition, we recognize the need to remain vigilant against uncertain global economic conditions. Fortunately, the luxury market, car market in particular, continues to show resilience and new automotive customers like GM will strengthen Harman’s access to the world’s top 3 vehicle markets.
We will continue to pursue growth in both established and emerging markets, positioning Harman as a diverse global player. Our strategic efforts over the last 5 years have now transformed Harman to a secular and balanced growth company. Our aggressive innovation focus will remain a critical element of this growth. As a prime example, Harman’s scalable system approach has reduced our development cost and dramatically shortened our time to market. Earlier this week, we announced we will acquire Interchain Solutions, a Bangalor, India-based infotainment and telematics company, with expertise in Google and Droid-based open system solutions. Together with our technology portfolio and talented engineers, we are well-equipped to compete on the global stage. We have built a globally competitive new Harman by taking out $450 million in permanent cost, by redirecting our capital investment, by realigning our sourcing for cost and currency and by rebalancing our workforce to best-cost countries, with 50% of our workforce now located in fast-growing, emerging markets.
Ladies and gentlemen, I have told you earlier that Harman’s strategy is to build an organization that can compete profitably in any economic cycle, and we are well-positioned now. We have worked hard to build a strong balance sheet that facilitates all of these pursuits, and in the last quarter we took advantage of market opportunity to repurchase our stock and announced the doubling of our dividend from $0.30 to $0.60. I am very proud of Harman’s management team, and thousands of employees worldwide who have embraced this culture of continuous improvement and performance culture. And we are committed to furthering this trend.
Before I ask my colleague Herbert Parker to take you through our key financial data, let me share a few highlights of fiscal year 2012. We outpaced the market, with sales up 16%, BRIC markets growth 31%, lagged by China at 42%, which obviously gave us a 41% increase in earnings per share. We posted our 11th consecutive quarter of improvement in both top and bottom line, with our EBITDA growing at a compound aggregate growth rate of 245% during this period. We have continued to book major, multi-year awards with leading automakers in Europe and Asia, while landing a new significant order from GM. We booked a record high $5.2 billion in automotive orders during fiscal 2012, and our automotive backlog now stands at a record high $16.1 billion, and now comes the real good news. This backlog of $16 billion now carried double-digit profit margin. This is the sure thing, which investors like to hear, that what the stream of revenue will look like in coming years. None of us could say that 4 years ago, 5 years ago, 2 years ago, but we worked on replenishing the bad business with good business, while running off the platforms which were generating low-margin business. That took lot of discipline, lot of courage, but we have built that culture now. We have more than doubled our patent portfolio in the last 5 years, and our new product pipeline has never been so rich and relevant. Our balance sheet is healthy, positioning Harman to readily meet its obligations and to search out strategic opportunity for growth.
With that, ladies and gentlemen, it’s been another exciting year at Harman. Our team is energized to carry this performance into fiscal year ’13, and we look forward to the continued support of our customers, employees and shareholders, who are cementing Harman’s position as the go-to global technology leader in audio infotainment.
Thank you for your attention, and I will now ask Chief Financial Officer Herbert Parker to provide some additional color on our fourth quarter and full-year results.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dinesh, and good morning to everyone. We’ve closed yet another very solid year of operational and financial improvement, and I’d like to review just a few of our highlights. As always, most of our financial comments are provided on a non-GA
componenttext:
Thank you, Dinesh, and good morning to everyone. We’ve closed yet another very solid year of operational and financial improvement, and I’d like to review just a few of our highlights. As always, most of our financial comments are provided on a non-GAAP basis, which basically excludes restructuring costs and other nonrecurring items. The reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP results is included in the release, but for your convenience, we took a $9.4 million charge in restructuring expense this fiscal year.
Okay, starting with the topline. We increased our annual revenues by 16% to $4.4 billion, and if you exclude the impact of foreign currency, we grew at a rate of 17%. We are pleased to have produced strong, double-digit growth in both the infotainment and lifestyle divisions, combined with the delivery of double-digit EBITDA percentages in all 3 operational divisions. I’d also like to point out that since fiscal 2009, our total automotive backlog has grown from $10.9 billion to $16.1 billion to-date, and this is an all-time record for Harman.
As shown in Slide 6 of our slide deck released today, this backlog growth is not only related to our existing business, but we have also grown our backlog of new business and new customers from $2.7 billion to $4.5 billion in the same time period.
Okay, speaking of our gross margin, it expanded by 90 basis points during the year, despite the headwinds we faced in the lifestyle and professional divisions from the neodymian commodity cost increases. The increase in margin percentage was driven by economies of scale on our fixed costs, coupled with our continued benefits from our ongoing global footprint initiative, and our relentless focus on cost efficiency. We also continued to improve in our control over costs. Our full-year SG&A expense declined by 60 basis points to 20.1% of sales, compared to the prior fiscal year, even though we were simultaneously increasing our investments in global brand awareness. These improvements translate into 150 basis points increase in operating income, representing another annual increase of nearly $100 million.
Net income for the year was $211 million, and our earnings per share were $2.93, compared to $2.08 per share in fiscal year 2011, this is a 41% increase. Our effective tax rate on a non-GAAP basis was 21.9%.
Now regarding the status of our balance sheet items, we reduced our year-end net operating capital as a percentage of annualized sales by 120 basis points to 11.6%. This was primarily driven by DSO and DPO improvements, which was also a key contributor to our ability to generate $260 million of cash from operating activities. As such, our immediate access to available cash, or total liquidity, now stands at $1.4 billion as of the end of this fiscal year, and this gives us sufficient capital to cover our future operating, financing and investing requirements.
Now for the benefit of any new investors, let me state our capital allocation philosophy. We follow the same type of disciplined approach for deploying our capital to the highest and best use as we do with the allocation of operational resources required to drive improvements into our P&L. Each alternative, whether it be an organic growth investment, acquisition or buyback, is indexed against each other and against the value that a stock buyback program provides as a key hurdle. Having said that, it is our belief and experience that long-term sustainable shareholder value is best created through investing in organic growth opportunities such as building our footprint in the BRIC countries, combined with accretive acquisitions that either add complementary technical capabilities or provide distribution access to emerging markets. We’ve also determined that the delivery of a growing sustainable dividend stream is an appropriate method to returning value to our shareholders.
All right, let me now just address a few guidance-related topics. As you know, we did issue guidance today. Since October, 2011, as you know, most global automaker production forecasts have come down. However, Harman’s market share gains, favorable customer mix, are helping to offset these headwinds. And we have updated our fiscal 2011 (sic) [2013] guidance for the foreign currency changes only, and we also have updated for the share count, so I’d like to emphasize and point out again that on a constant currency basis on local currencies, we are maintaining our previous guidance provided in October, 2011.
Finally, I’d like to also note that we have now assumed a tax rate in the range of 26 to 28% for fiscal year 2013. In conclusion, financially we’ve become increasingly strong. Our profitability continues to improve. We have a strong balance sheet to achieve our growth plans. Most importantly, we’ve brought a great deal of cost discipline into the company and that is now a part of our culture.
Operator, we are now ready to take your questions.

componenttext: Chris, we are not allowed to reveal a lot more.  This is well under development, on a very good path. This will be state of the art system, and we’re not allowed to mention what models will go and what competitor it’s replacing. But we are very pleased that the first time Harman has been asked to come in, and we’re very excited. I’m personally very excited, I’ll oversee that program myself to the last success, as I did Chrysler program myself because GM/Chrysler both, they set the benchmark here.  Chrysler had just launched beautifully, no bugs, nothing, great technology. And GM will be sometimes 2014 end is what we’re targeting.

So that helps us fine-tune how our purchasing decisions should be.

componenttext: Yes, okay, Chris.  The structured tax rate is 30%, but as we are able to utilize a lot of discrete items from reductions in countries like Germany and other countries like that, it reduces the tax rate. Another factor, Chris, is that we’re starting to make more profits in North America now, and as you know that has a higher tax rate then we do in most other jurisdictions, that’s the main driver.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Could you just provide a little bit more color, maybe on the trend at Lifestyle? It looks like that the change in revenues, ex-currency inflected higher to up 39% year-over-year this quarter versus 22% year-over-year last quarter. What accounts for that i
componenttext: Could you just provide a little bit more color, maybe on the trend at Lifestyle? It looks like that the change in revenues, ex-currency inflected higher to up 39% year-over-year this quarter versus 22% year-over-year last quarter. What accounts for that increase? Is it mostly on the automotive/audio side, or is there anything to report on the consumer side of things?

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: It’s both, Ryan.  We had an excellent growth in car audio, almost 28%. But then you need to do some put and take. 3% of the growth in Lifestyle came from neodymium surcharge which we billed, and that came at 0 margin. So that’s the thing. So 28% and y
componenttext: It’s both, Ryan.  We had an excellent growth in car audio, almost 28%. But then you need to do some put and take. 3% of the growth in Lifestyle came from neodymium surcharge which we billed, and that came at 0 margin. So that’s the thing. So 28% and you can adjust for 3% neodymium.  We had a healthy gain of also double digit in Home and Multimedia, and for those of you who have been following Harman long time, our consumer business, now we call it Home and Multimedia under Lifestyle, traditionally has struggled and not made money, but now we are at mid-single digit operating profits, so we made a turnaround, and we are double digits growth. So all in all very good year for Lifestyle. And it also underscores why we made this change when we put consumer and car audio together, we are able to see the branding and marketing dollars really helping us connect consumers, those who are buying home office, on-the-go products and the car audio brands. And we are seeing the take rates going up, and I expect this division to continue to do margin expansion and topline expansion in ’13,’14, ’15.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great. That’s really helpful to get that breakdown and color.  Just on infotainment, it looks like your FY '13 infotainment guidance does not seem to imply margin expansion relative to what you were able to achieve in FY '12, maybe on not flowing throug
componenttext: Great. That’s really helpful to get that breakdown and color.  Just on infotainment, it looks like your FY '13 infotainment guidance does not seem to imply margin expansion relative to what you were able to achieve in FY '12, maybe on not flowing through the, what was a real strong quarter this quarter. I’m just wondering, what is the driver of that assumption though given that you should continue to transition clients, from the lower margin customized to the higher margin scalable systems over the course of the year?

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Couple things.  First of all we should explain to you that we confirmed the range of our guidance. And if you look at our range of guidance for 2012, for Infotainment it was $160 million to $175 million operating profit, and we landed at $182 million. So
componenttext: Couple things.  First of all we should explain to you that we confirmed the range of our guidance. And if you look at our range of guidance for 2012, for Infotainment it was $160 million to $175 million operating profit, and we landed at $182 million. So we did beat it nicely. So having said that, rather than tweaking the guidance for one division here and there, we just left it. We wanted to come out, we’re not changing our guidance, we’re leaving it as it is. Actually midpoint of the guidance tells you where we’ll be, and we're going to definitely have an improvement.  So we already landed 7.6% this year, the guidance it starts with 7% and goes to 8.2% if you the quick math, for revenue and operating income. So clearly, we have a possibility to come out in the top half of the guidance, and hopefully even beat it. But a lot of things are still uncertain. And the last item, Ryan, which is important, also Chris’s point and other colleagues, that some of the programs are rolling off in ’13, and our high margin programs would be early in the ramp-up phase. That’s why revenue is ’13 slightly breathing sort of exercise, ’14, ’15 we hit it up on the high gear again. And that would be good margin expansion at the same time, good top line because we’ll be ramping a bunch of programs.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's great.  And then just last question, you reported that your China revenues were up 42% year-over-year, which is very interesting. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about, maybe just qualitatively segment by segment what the drive
componenttext: Okay, that's great.  And then just last question, you reported that your China revenues were up 42% year-over-year, which is very interesting. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about, maybe just qualitatively segment by segment what the drivers are for the sales in your 3 different divisions in China or other emerging markets.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. China, let’s start with China. China did of course -- all 3 divisions had very good growth that’s why the average was 31% for the company. But Lifestyle literally exceeded everything in car audio. As I have said in my earlier calls, emerging mar
componenttext: Okay. China, let’s start with China. China did of course -- all 3 divisions had very good growth that’s why the average was 31% for the company. But Lifestyle literally exceeded everything in car audio. As I have said in my earlier calls, emerging market consumers when they’re buying cars happen to be the first time in their family if not first time in their village, first time in the city. And they want to have some things in it which they can appreciate and audio is one of those. So take rates in emerging markets will continue to go up and that’s why building brand is very important. So you will see that. And Infotainment -- so let’s stick with Lifestyle first, Lifestyle had good healthy, more than 50% growth, which is phenomenal, that’s coming from consumer products and car audio. And then of course Infotainment we had also good 30%, 35% growth and Professional had in 20s. So we’re building lot of ARPUs and some of the revenues would be booked perhaps in early year. So I expect all 3 divisions to hit 30-plus-percent growth or even higher in 2013. Moving on to China -- I mean India and Brazil or Russia. Brazil we have an opportunity because we have not even begun our operation in infotainment. We only do pro-audio and part of car-audio so opportunities are immense. I expect ’13, ’14 to take us to the next level. India with a good growth but with the $200-plus-million order from Tata motors and that will be commissioned, engineered and shipped out of India, I think we’ll start to see good development not in ’13, but ’14 will be bumper year for India. But ’13 should be a good year for Lifestyle and for pro-audio anyway. And Russia, I think we had a good development. We don’t do anything in infotainment in Russia, and we do a little bit of pro-audio, little bit of Lifestyle and that to mainly consumer. But Russia is on our radar screen for ’13 and ’14. So we as a management, first focused on China, then focused on Brazil then India and Russia and now all 4 will be on sort of top gear.

So it was higher for the quarter, but for the year, we’re pretty much in line where we expected to be.

componenttext: Perfect, that’s totally fine.  And one last big picture question for you, Dinesh, what’s the benefit of bringing Interchange in house?  I mean is this something that you’re going to be looking to do going forward?  Or was there something specific here that you wanted to get in terms of skills or patents or something?

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Not so much patents, but it is to do with open source solutions.  We got out of Q&X operating systems Ravi, more than a couple years now.  We want to be operating system agnostic.  So we continue to use Q&X as our fundamental operating system, which we st
componenttext: Not so much patents, but it is to do with open source solutions.  We got out of Q&X operating systems Ravi, more than a couple years now.  We want to be operating system agnostic.  So we continue to use Q&X as our fundamental operating system, which we still believe most robust from safety point of view.  But we are now developing Android-based infotainment, Lenox and Droid, Microsoft, everything, so we will have -- and systems will not be unique to one operating system.  The colonel could be one thing and apps could be written in something else.  It’s going to be a hybrid system, which is what actually [indiscernible] in Europe is sort of calling for and talking to more BMW and Audis who lead the space with us. They seem to be very comfortable with the strategy we have. So this little company we acquired, this will give us additional horsepower to expedite our engineering development work.  In addition, we’re also adding some 100 software engineering resources and Google and Droid based competence right here in Midwest, in Ann Arbor and Chicago area. Lots of people from Google actually have left to join Harman.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Understood. And just speaking of Q&X, RIM is obviously having a few difficulties right now.  Can you remind us again how things stand between you and your ability to use Q&X, especially if RIM kind of licenses someone else or partners with someone else?
componenttext: Understood. And just speaking of Q&X, RIM is obviously having a few difficulties right now.  Can you remind us again how things stand between you and your ability to use Q&X, especially if RIM kind of licenses someone else or partners with someone else?

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: That’s a great question for all of our listeners.  When we sold Q&X to RIM, we took care of our shareholders interest for next 20 years.  We have access to the source code of Q&X no matter what change of hands happen.  Even if company goes so south that
componenttext: That’s a great question for all of our listeners.  When we sold Q&X to RIM, we took care of our shareholders interest for next 20 years.  We have access to the source code of Q&X no matter what change of hands happen.  Even if company goes so south that no one can save it, still we will have access to it.  And frankly speaking, we have as much confidence in Q&X as RIM today.  And we have an excellent relationship, so there’s no issue of access to source and access to development for next 18, 20 years.

componenttext: Okay. And just in Europe just in case things get much worse very quickly, what’s your temporary workforce over there as a percentage of the overall workforce?

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. Typically, Adam, what we have done now and this is a transformation over the last 3 years, we used to have almost 100% permanent workforce and now we’ve gone almost 80/20 model.  So we have 80% permanent workforce.  And to deal with increase in dem
componenttext: Yes. Typically, Adam, what we have done now and this is a transformation over the last 3 years, we used to have almost 100% permanent workforce and now we’ve gone almost 80/20 model.  So we have 80% permanent workforce.  And to deal with increase in demand like in 2012, we are able to bring in temporary workforce, which is easy to reduce if the demand goes down.  It’s of course much easier to work with in Hungary, which is our largest manufacturing in the world, much easier to deal with Mexico and China and other places.  So that’s why I made a big point in my earlier comments that we are actually very well positioned now to deal with economic ups and downs when it comes to our manufacturing cost.  We can adjust it rather quickly than in the past.

componenttext: That answers my question.  I just wanted to make sure I understood the methodology. And then, Dinesh, as we look at 2013 in your guidance here and I understand there’s a range there, but if we take the midpoint of the range, then we look at where the earnings performance comes from, you’ve done a great job on the Infotainment side, but incrementally here the Lifestyle and Professional are going to be the primary earnings drivers in 2013.  We haven’t really talked about what’s going on in those businesses.  Can you take a little bit of time of what the revenue drivers and the margin drivers are in those 2 pieces of business here looking at 2013?

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: David, first of all, I'm really smiling and happy.  You’re my hero because you’re asking me now Professional and Lifestyle questions. I mean in the past, all the calls, we spend 99% of the time on Infotainment, which I’m glad that because we have tu
componenttext: David, first of all, I'm really smiling and happy.  You’re my hero because you’re asking me now Professional and Lifestyle questions. I mean in the past, all the calls, we spend 99% of the time on Infotainment, which I’m glad that because we have turned the corner.  You guys seem to be pleased with the way we’re doing. So let’s come back to Lifestyle and Professional.  You are absolutely spot on that Lifestyle and Pro had been from neodymium.  And that is gone away.  We will not talk about neodymium even if the prices are still higher, we have resolved that and we took care of that business. Second, Professional launched 140 brand new products earlier in the year, especially in the main bread and butter area of in-store sound and touring sound in the loud speaker area and that business has just taken off.  So I expect really to be beating our last year’s sales topline growth rate definitely in Pro.  I expect that.  And Lifestyle has done a very good job dealing with all this neodymium issue and ramping [indiscernible] facility, Mexico and Dandong.  Both of these divisions, and that’s totally behind us so that should be falling off the bottom line for the margin expansion. At the same time, I’m getting ready in 2 weeks’ time to go to Berlin, we’ll have the world’s largest home multimedia show where we’ll launch the 25 brand new products.  That’s the highest I’ve ever seen.  No more than 5 products every year, so this is 25 products.  So I think we expect quite a good topline at the same time you know we’re very disciplined when it comes to pricing and pricing premium.  So we’re holding on quite well, so I expect both of these divisions to grow topline with new products, to grow topline from the new markets and Pro and Lifestyle both will also benefit from North America, all the slow pickup, but nice pickup.  Both of them are seeing very good inquiry for the quotes.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, great.  And then how much -- do you know offhand how much neodymium headwinds you have that -- to catch up yet in the first part of 2013 because I don’t think you got that all straightened away until partway through the year.
componenttext: Okay, great.  And then how much -- do you know offhand how much neodymium headwinds you have that -- to catch up yet in the first part of 2013 because I don’t think you got that all straightened away until partway through the year.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: 2012, we said last time that we will be done with this no matter what, that was a personal goal I made and team made.  And we are done with it in terms of never mentioning that, even if it is a bit of a headwind, we will find ways to compensate.  Mostly w
componenttext: 2012, we said last time that we will be done with this no matter what, that was a personal goal I made and team made.  And we are done with it in terms of never mentioning that, even if it is a bit of a headwind, we will find ways to compensate.  Mostly we have passed it on to our customers so it’s in their pricing index. If neodymium goes down to where it used to be 1 year ago, then our customers will get a break, if not, it’s there.  At the same time, we have also had pretty advanced development in material sciences to find substitute to replace neo with better acoustics capabilities and we are doing that in design changes.  So I think between those, neodymium is quite under control. And in terms of capacity, margin, the margin expansion for new neo, that would drop straight bottom line, you should count on that.  And then when it comes to capacity in Mexico and China, there we’re going to be ramping -- we’re ramped up already, but all the products for China factory will be running at 80% production capacity.  That will help us fast expanding Asian market, China, India, Vietnam, Indonesia, they are really booming and so I expect topline for Pro to be much stronger than 2012. And then Lifestyle can come close to what they did last year, I’d be happy.  Last year was an amazing topline, which may be sustainable, we’ll see, but profit expansion is the key.

componenttext: No, no, we’re not expecting to be lower because we’re investing heavily in our global brands and we’re seeing good payback, so we would continue to do that.  It would only -- it would definitely not be lower.  We may stay at that rate if we find a different savings, different strategy, but it would not be lower.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Doug Thomas [ph] from JET Investment research.  Please proceed.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Doug Thomas [ph] from JET Investment research.  Please proceed.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Dinesh, I was wondering, I think sometimes people mistake what’s going on in the industries and actually, don’t think about -- maybe they have the opposite argument they need to take, but on the General Motors thing, you’ve said before, you thought
componenttext: Dinesh, I was wondering, I think sometimes people mistake what’s going on in the industries and actually, don’t think about -- maybe they have the opposite argument they need to take, but on the General Motors thing, you’ve said before, you thought you could win them over but and that would be -- I don’t want to put words in your mouth, but clearly you said it would have to be economically beneficial for you guys.  And I’m wondering in light of that, given what’s going on, particularly in Europe and Asia, I know there’s a lot of concerns out there on the growth of the -- in the auto market, particularly on the low end.  What’s the sales process look like at this point in time?  In other words, I would imagine as competitive as things have gotten in certain sectors, and as much pressure as there are in people like a Fiat and Ford in Europe and so forth that what you guys have to offer them would be much more valuable going forward from a competitive point of view and from a cost point of view than when things are booming, for example, and they can sell whatever they make.  Am I -- is that -- are you seeing that reflected from your conversations with customers?

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Doug, you try not to put words in my mouth, but you sure did.  I mean, you said all the right things what I would have said.  First of all, the culture in this company is all about pricing and premium pricing.  So GM business is a win-win.  GM gets superb
componenttext: Doug, you try not to put words in my mouth, but you sure did.  I mean, you said all the right things what I would have said.  First of all, the culture in this company is all about pricing and premium pricing.  So GM business is a win-win.  GM gets superb technology, the latest cutting edge and we get what we deserve for what we bring.  And then you mentioned the impact in Europe, the economy, what happens to Fiat, Chrysler and some of the European automakers, that’s why we do track OEMs into 3 different categories. One, we say all OEMs globally, they are going to grow about 4%, 4.5%.  Then we look at Harman OEMs, including Chrysler, Fiat, Hyundai, Tata, Geely, German automakers, they’re going to grow about 2%.  Then we look at Harman OEMs, pure luxury, Porsche, Audi, BMW, Tata.  They’re going to grow 0.3%.  So if you put it all together and do the weighted average, find out, we’re going to be growing 3x the growth of the car companies, which means we’ll be taking market share and why can I say with such confidence?  Because we have production releases out in our hands already for the next 6 months and we’re quite pleased. And on top of that ,if I may, we’re seeing clearly all of these global players, they may see some slowdown in their mature markets, but they continue to see growth in India, China, Brazil, Russia.  In India, they’re starting from almost near 0, they’re growing 40%, 50% a year, Infotainment growth, car audio growth.  And China would grow also some 15% to 20% a year.  So this is very healthy for us.  And since we are on the market, we’re on the ground, we have R&D, engineering, manufacturing, so I also want to make a quick point for the benefit of all listeners, that we have arrived where a good company should be. That means serve your customers close to where they are.  So we’re serving Chinese customers whether they are German automakers in China or Asian customers, we’re serving them from China. We’re serving German automakers from Germany from Hungary, American automakers from Mexico and the United States.  So logistic costs and also proximity saves us money and improves the quality. And you get premium for that from automakers.  I mean the days are gone when Japanese pushed their technology and everything was coming from Japan.  It still does, by the way, for some of our competitors, but that’s really not going to allow you to be on top of the technology. One more thing I’ll point here, we opened last couple years a wonderful R&D lab in Palo Alto.  That’s expensive, but it’s very necessary to keep in touch with technology, what's happening in connective space.  And we’re opening up another open source R&D, I mentioned in Ann Arbor and Chicago area to really be on the leading side on Android open-source systems. There’s a lot happening all towards the future.  We’re not about 1 quarter or 1 year maximization of profit, Doug. In fact, the continuous improvement is coming because we took some very drastic steps 3 years ago, 2 years ago. So we will never deter to do that.  So all in all we feel good about it for 2013 in spite of some uncertainty. One could say am I cautiously optimistic? I think I’m more towards optimistic; I'm going to still use the word cautiously, that’s fine.

componenttext: We had an exceptional year, but we’ve gone down actually the last 4 years, David, from 19% of sales down to 11.6% now. So we'd like to stay at that level, but that’s going to be a challenge obviously, but we think that’s a good number. I’m not going to look for too much improvement over that number.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, Dinesh, we haven’t talked a lot here at all lately on the infotainment side as it relates to Mercedes. I don’t think you have a lot of business left there. But can you give us some perspective on where that stands -- that relati
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, Dinesh, we haven’t talked a lot here at all lately on the infotainment side as it relates to Mercedes. I don’t think you have a lot of business left there. But can you give us some perspective on where that stands -- that relationship stands today?

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, sure, first of all start with the relationship. We have a very good relationship. We will be launching brand new system called NPV 5 [ph] early next year. And that would be the next generation system they will launch and that will go live. As you kn
componenttext: Well, sure, first of all start with the relationship. We have a very good relationship. We will be launching brand new system called NPV 5 [ph] early next year. And that would be the next generation system they will launch and that will go live. As you know historically, prior to my time coming in Harman, they did bring in 2 other suppliers. So we continue to be 3 of us, 2 Japanese and 1 American, Harman. So between 3 of us we split roughly 1/3, 1/3 of their infotainment business and that’s sort of continuing. And there is a follow-on award will be coming in the next 3 to 6 months which we are also bidding. So until then hold the horses that what would it look like next year. But in audio side we also have a decent business. We did mention in our press release as well as slide deck that Harman current business with Mercedes has been extended on some of the models, so that’s always very nice. And in terms of business I think since it’s not 10% of our sales we don’t put out in the 10-K, but it’s a healthy business.  It’s still our third or fourth largest business after BMW and VW group. Fiat Chrysler is now becoming third largest and Daimler is our fourth largest.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: I know you guys have mentioned before that you work with the Googles and Apples of the world as far as integrating the smartphone into the infotainment platform, but can you please talk about some of the competitive advantages that you have versus the Goo
componenttext: I know you guys have mentioned before that you work with the Googles and Apples of the world as far as integrating the smartphone into the infotainment platform, but can you please talk about some of the competitive advantages that you have versus the Googles and Apples of the world as far as, maybe it’s relationships or safety feature patents that you have in infotainment systems that they can’t necessarily replicate.

headline: Harman International Industries Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think you hit it, David, active safety integration is the single biggest differentiator. Beyond that what goes in the car, as you know, has 50 to 100 live sensors in an advanced car and you’ve got 5, 6 sub-systems in the car and we are the primary pro
componenttext: I think you hit it, David, active safety integration is the single biggest differentiator. Beyond that what goes in the car, as you know, has 50 to 100 live sensors in an advanced car and you’ve got 5, 6 sub-systems in the car and we are the primary provider. We have a backbone, a software backbone. We write some 3 million to 3.5 million lines of code. So a lot of interaction with the live sensors, live information while car is on the road. And we are able to manipulate that data and use that to determine the best route calculation. The best eco route if you’re on a green car. So a lot of those things would not be possible for smartphones ever because they would not have that access. And why so? Car companies are nervous, for good reasons, to allow more than just a basic integration capability with smartphones, because smartphones carry hundreds of applications which were written by kids anywhere from age 13 to 17 years, especially in the case of Google. Any they really don’t know much about car and how this will interact with the safety of the car, a lot of other engine safety, braking system. So this is where the system competence and car eco-system knowledge comes in play. Therefore I’ve always said, David, that going forward, both smart integration of the telephone and embedded system will co-exist. Because the starting points are fairly low and we will lead, both will continue to integrate Google phone, Nokia phone, Microsoft, Blackberry and other phones will come in the market. Example is good. Look at Chrysler, what we just launched last week. This will be agnostic to any phone, see if you just had an iPhone what good it is if someone walks in the car with an Android phone then you are out of luck. So we will provide technology which will allow integration of any phone for basic level of turn-by-turn, point of interest, traffic advisory. So that’s the biggest advantage, and I think car companies get it. That’s why you can see in the last 6 to 12 months the kind of flurry of large awards we have received from BMW, GM and many others.
